awd_titl_txt: Characeristics of Island-scale Airflow and Climate over the Hawaiian Islands
awd_abstract_narration:
The Hawaiian Islands, which present a variety of terrain heights and configurations embedded within a synoptically- and interannually-modulated trade wind regime, constitute a natural laboratory for high-resolution studies of orographic flow and precipitation processes at subtropical latitudes.  A combination of careful reanalysis of nearly 10 years of archived high-resolution (1.5- and 3.0-km island-scale) numerical forecasts generated using the MM5/LSM (the paired Penn State/NCAR mesoscale/land-surface model) and WRF (Weather Research & Forecasting model) and select re-runs will be used to explore a variety of questions including but not limited to:  (1) Why is Mount Wai'ale'ale (1598 m MSL) on Kauai one of the wettest spots on earth?; (2) What physical processes are responsible for a lee-side summer rainfall maximum on Kona?; (3) what dynamics control diurnal and seasonal variations in strong channel winds in the zone separating Hawaii and Maui?; (4) How does reverse flow in the wake of relatively lower barriers such as Oahu depend on trade-wind properties?; (5) How do El Nino-induced modulations affect the micro-climates of zones both above and below the trade-wind inversion across the Hawaiian archipelago?; and (6) What specific conditions favor development of trapped mountain lee waves in this region?

The intellectual merit of this research rests on extension of model-based representations and associated dynamical understanding of island-atmosphere interactions across the Hawaiian archipelago to finer scales than has heretofore been possible, and within a zone where El Nino/Southern Oscillation-induced impacts are both sizable yet incompletely characterized.  Broader impacts will include graduate student training but extend to improved understanding of conditions impacting commerce and transportation, fragile marine and terrestrial ecosystems, and capacity for renewable energy generation.

por.por_cntn:
Our study improves our basic understanding of orographically induced airflow and weather over the Hawai'ian Islands and adjacent coastal waters including: strong winds within ocean channels; afternoon heavy rain showers under weak trades; trapped mountain lee waves; and downslope wind storms and impacts of trade wind strength on island-scale airflow, island wakes and local weather. We identified the large-scale settings for the occurrences of these localized weather events and demonstrated the capability of the high-resolution models in simulating these events in real-time operational settings. We also improved our basic understanding of the diurnal cycle, seasonal cycle, and two types of ENSO events on microscale climate.  The results from this study are also applicable to other mountainous subtropical/tropical islands over different parts of the world.

Based on this research, we conducted downscaling to island scale, high resolution regional and island-scale simulations, and real-time forecasts for the Hawai'ian Islands.  Our high-resolution daily island-scale model output has been used: 1) as a guidance grid within the National Weather Service (NWS) Honolulu Forecast Office Interactive Forecast Preparation System/Graphic Forecast Editor (IFPS/GFE) with a 2.5-km grid; 2) by the Hawai'i Natural Energy Institute (HNEI) at the University of Hawaiʻi at Mānoa for wave energy forecasts at the U.S. Navy's Wave Energy Test Site (WETS), off Marine Corps Base Hawaiʻi,  and assessment of wave energy resources along the Hawai'ian Island chain; 3) by ocean modelers to drive a series of real-time wave, ocean and coastal models; 4) for the study of local weather conditions for wildfires; 5) for site selection of Oahu offshore wind farms; 6)  for the study of the impact of volcanic air pollution on school children over the Big Island; 7) by the USGS for the study of coral connectivity in the Maui Nu complex of Hawai'i. Our model data are available to researchers who need microscale weather/climate conditions for various applications, and a diverse set of stockholders, including the general public, government agencies, tourist industry, inter-island shipping, and can be downloaded from our ftp site.  Our twice daily 72-h model forecasts are available at our website: http://www.soest.hawaii.edu/MET/Faculty/wrf/arw/.

Our team also studied localized heavy rainfall events over Taiwan during the early summer rainy season.  One of the important findings from our studies is on the relationship between the horizontal moisture transport by the Marine Boundary Layer Jet (MBLJ) from the northern southern China Sea to the Taiwan area and the heavy rainfall occurrences over Taiwan. The subsynoptic Low-Level Jet (SLLJ) is part of the secondary circulations associated with the Mei-Yu jet/ front system with the maximum wind axis extending vertically upward in the frontal zone. The moisture transport by the MBLJ provides the moisture source, whereas the vertical lifting by the jet/front system and orographic effects is the main cause for the rainfall production.

We also developed a technique to initialize our high-resolution weather models with a well-defined tropical cyclone structure that is well adjusted to the environment conditions it is embedded.   For all cases considered, the dynamical initialization scheme produces reasonable storm structure, eyewall, spiral rainbands and size with an intensity close to the best track data at the model initial time. The scheme works well in predicting track, structure, size and especially the intensity.  This is because at the model initial time, the initial storm intensity and structure are well adjusted to the environmental conditions in which it is embedded and well adapted to the model employed.  With better initial conditions in the models, our technique improves the forecasts of track, intensity, and structure of tropical cyclones.
